Description: Lentoid flask with two vertical handles: the body is opaque amethyst glass with glossy surface. On the rim is a prefabricated white and amethyst cord. The body decorations are in white, yellow, and turquoise-blue and are of fine quality. The handles were overlaid with five white and yellow threads. One handle is lost, two gaps in the body. On one side at the shoulder there is a small patch indicating misfiring - a rare detail in Egyptian vessels. A small section at the base of the handle is concave. Within the vessel is a small packet of amethyst glass fragments presumably found with the flask.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Ghurab, from a pit with ashes
Curator's comments: The close similarity of this flask to 1890,1108.1 which is firmly dated to the time of Ramses II could be used as an argument for a similar dating, but as these flasks continued to be duplicated over many generations it is sounder to give a wide date range. Bibliography: W. M. F. Petrie, ‘Illahun, Kahun and Gurob’ 1889-1890 (London 1891), pl. XVII, fig. 35; B. Nolte, ‘Die Glasgefässe in Alten Ägypten (Berlin 1968), 71, pl. XVIII, 22.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1891 / Illahun, Kahun and Gurob (p. 17, pl. XVII)
Acquisition name: Donated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
